MainHeading.Title: Supplementary Estimates, 1983. - Vote 41: Transport (Resumed).
MainHeading.P: Debate resumed on the following motion:

That a supplementary sum not exceeding £10 be granted to defray the charge which will come in course of payment during the year ending on the 31st day of December, 1983, for the salaries and expenses of the Office of the Minister for Transport, including certain services administered by that Office, for a cost alleviation payment and for payment of certain grants and a grant-in-aid.
—(Minister for Transport.)

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Speaker.P: The Minister has an enormous responsibility and a difficult task facing him. The transport business is worth about £2,000 million, equal to about 16 per cent of GNP, but because of the lack of attention given to the industry in the past it has become the Cinderella of our economy. For example, public investment has been only about 1 per cent of GNP, far less than has been the case in the area of telecommunications and other vital services. This neglect will have to be reversed during the coming years.

The most important thing that has held back transport in the past few years is that it has been bedevilled by a complete lack of decision-making. There have been a number of reports in the past ten years outlining the need for reform in various areas. One was the road freight report which highlighted the restrictions on road freight and the extent to which that was increasing the cost to industry with regard to transport of goods. One figure quoted was 25 per cent extra cost in Ireland compared with other countries and part of that at least is due to road freight restrictions. This report had been acted on in part but all the recommendations have not been implemented.

There have been many studies of CIE and it is regrettable that none of the major recommendations in this area has been acted on. The Transport Consultative Commission reported on the need to set up a Dublin Transport Authority but despite numerous gestures by Ministers that this was to be done, three years after publication of the report the necessary measures have not been put before this House. Perhaps the greatest debacle of all was the much-vaunted £1,000 million road plan in 1980. That plan is in shreds and few of the proposals have been implemented.

MainHeading.P: We do not have far to go to see why these numerous reports have been left on shelves gathering dust. The reason is that responsibility in the area of transport has been scattered throughout different Departments and authorities. In the case of roads, the responsibility lies with local authorities throughout the country and with the Department of the Environment. I believe the Department of the Environment and the local authorities would freely admit that their prime responsibility is for housing and their secondary responsibility, from my experience in local authorities, is concern for employment and a greater emphasis on the need to have maintenance programmes going ahead rather than the major structual changes needed to improve our transport system. I cannot see that continuing to leave such a large area of responsibility in a Department whose primary responsibility does not rest in the transport area, is a good decision. This will have to be examined during the next few years.

We have responsibility for public transport scattered among a number of semi-State bodies, CIE, Aer Lingus and so on. The Government have been a reluctant paymaster for those bodies in many cases but I do not believe the Government have seriously got to grips with the policy decisions, the public transport options, which must be examined if we are to have proper development of public transport. They have reluctantly approved proposals coming from those bodies but they have not moved in and decided on the policy options. That failure has been highlighted in a number of reports, particularly reports by the NESC and McKinsey, when they examined our public transport. They criticised the Department of Transport for being unable or unwilling to go in and make the policy decisions needed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Unable under the law.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Speaker.P: That is a question of law reform. The question of traffic management is equally scattered. We have the Garda, the Department of Justice, the local authorities and the Department of Transport taking some responsibility in those areas. The scattering of responsibility must be responsible for the slowness in coming to grips with the type of changes in traffic management that have been proposed over the years. The implications of this failure to take decisions are serious. Things are being delayed and we also have decisions made which cannot be made in unison. If development in the area of roads and development in the area of rail are scattered between different authorities I cannot but believe that some investment decisions are made that are inconsistent in many ways.

MainHeading.P: I believe competing investments must be assessed together and in the same way. Any conflict between them should be resolved before large sums of public money are devoted to them. It is particularly welcome that we have a Minister and a Minister of State in this Department who have a reputation for couragous decision-making and an appetite for work. I believe their efforts will be richly rewarded in this Department over the coming years.

I would like to deal with some specific areas in public transport. I believe Dublin city has suffered from the failure to bring in the Dublin Transport Authority sooner. When the Transport Consultative Commission reported in March 1980 they suggested a timetable of legislation within six months and a short-term traffic management strategy to be carried out within three years. We have not yet seen the legislation and the short-term traffic management strategy has only been started. This is important because the Transport Consultative Commission pointed out that they believed the Dublin Transport Authority would immediately implement low cost improvements which could improve the traffic flow in Dublin and also that they would introduce a system of evaluating competing claims of road, bus and rail on public money. The delay in bringing forward those low cost improvements and proposals to evaluate investment cannot but be a case of counting pennies but flaunting the millions. The pennies that would have been devoted to the proposals of the Dublin Transport Authority have not gone ahead but the millions in investment continue to roll on in the various sectors.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: That was with the draftsman a long while ago.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Speaker.P: No doubt it was, but we have not seen anything in this House yet. When the Transport Consultative Commission drew up their report they drew attention to the importance of bringing in the Dublin Transport Authority. They cited the scattered responsibility and the way it was delaying effective decision-making in the transport area. They gave one example, which was very striking at the time, the attempt to bring the bus lane into Parliament Street. They cited the fact that 11 different bodies had to be consulted. The process of consultation meant that the time that elapsed between initiation of the proposals and their final implementation was two years. The fact that the decision makers still must refer to those 11 bodies in some way and that they can only work more speedily by a system of coaxing and co-operation is bound to hold back progress in this area. It is also precluding the establishment of real expertise in the transport area by the Dublin Transport Authority, which ought now to have been set up.

Another problem which has arisen, because of the failure to bring in the Dublin Transport Authority, is that many of the more novel ideas proposed by the Transport Consultative Commission have had to be left on the shelf. It is welcome to see that the bus lane proposal has gone ahead. There is significant improvement in the traffic flow as a result. Other proposals have not been implemented, such as off-peak delivery, car pooling, better school transport scheduling, more flexiblity in the time of opening of businesses and schools, suggestions in relation to pedestrian and cycle policies, proposals in relation to a more effective parking policy for the city — a traffic warden system with more than just the function of putting parking fine notices on vehicles but also with some control responsibility so that they would be able, in the event of traffic jams, cars creating an obstruction, to direct people to remove them. Those sort of proposals have not gone ahead because they needed more than just willingness to put them through. They needed legislative authority to push them through and, as a result, they have fallen behind.

MainHeading.P: The Transport Task Force have not begun to look at the investment options, which were to be one of the first responsibilities of the Dublin Transport Authority. It may be said that no major decisions in the area of transport have been made in the last few years. I do not believe that answers the criticism entirely because there is no doubt that routine spending goes on or, if it does not, certain services are being chopped off. If services are chopped off, or some investment decisions go ahead without reference to the wider economic value of those services, inevitably some of the money will go astray.

If the money is short and decisions are postponed perhaps sometimes the wrong decisions are postponed, and here I believe that there has been a significant loss by virtue of failure to have an evaluation authority. A matter that springs to mind that would affect my constituency is the fact that the proposal to have feeder services to the suburban railway lines has not been implemented. If large sums of money are being spent and have been spent on a rapid suburban rail service it is only logical that the far cheaper feeder services from the centres of population should have been in place to match that investment.

I am glad that the Minister said in his speech at the opening of this discussion that the CIE subsidy would in future be given on the above-the-line basis — in other words, CIE would not be in the continuous situation of having a deficit and the Government coming in and picking up the deficit. That is bad for management procedure in the company and has brought undue criticism on CIE for appearing to make losses and costing the taxpayer more than necessary. Those criticisms may or may not be justified, but that form of presentation is bound to bring public criticism on CIE.

However, it will not be enough merely to switch what is essentially a block grant from the bottom of the line to just above the line. The Government must go further than just accepting the idea that CIE should apply for a block amount of money, receive that at the beginning of the year and allow it to go above the line. The decision as to the level of that grant must be based on some sort of microknowledge of the various services involved. CIE have itemised the deficit into rail and bus and various major services, but if we are to make rational decisions about how much should be given to CIE as a subsidy we must look at it per route and per service and go into considerably more desegregation than exists at present. I cannot see that subsidies towards road freight should be dealt with in the same breath as subsidies towards transport for the elderly. We should set out clear-cut criteria on which we will give subsidies to CIE and, therefore, know what we are paying for and let CIE live within those guidelines. The Minister must go beyond the idea of simply shifting the subsidy to above the line. If the Government feel that such microinterference or examination of CIE's runnings——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: They cannot do it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Speaker.P: ——is too difficult or should not be brought in, a possible alternative is to ask CIE to work within a criterion such as, for example, in the case of passenger services they would be under a certain budget constraint and they would be asked to maximise the number of passenger miles within that budget constraint. I understand that such criteria have been given to transport authorities in the UK and have met with some success. If the detailed examination of CIE's books, which I would favour, does not meet with Government approval, perhaps that option would be investigated instead.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: It probably would meet with Government approval but would CIE approve? This is the problem.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Speaker.P: There is also a greater need for a Government role in other areas of CIE operations. The NESC have proposed that the five-year rolling corporate plans be brought in for CIE. Under these plans they would set out their objectives which would be monitored. They would set out their investment plans and management would have explicit responsibility for bad investment decisions. Probably the problem has dogged many areas of semi-State activity where notably bad decisions have been made in the past few years, but it seems at the end of the day that nobody is specifically responsible for the overruns of spending or for what materialises as bad market projections and so on. We must bring into our semi-State bodies — particularly in the transport area because of its importance to the economy — more responsibility for the investment decisions.

In passing, I must say I was disappointed that when I went to the Library to review CIE matters the last account I could find was for 1979 and it seems that in 1983 CIE have not yet come up with their 1980 accounts. It is bad that the accounts of a semi-State body responsible for such enormous sums of money have not been presented to the House at this stage.

In the context of five-year plans such as I have mentioned, in recent years the only sort of planning seems to have been a mass of all-or-nothing proposals. The idea of rapid rail was brought forward as an all-or-nothing proposal presented to the Government. It would be better to have a more detailed investment programme showing the more minor decisions and the justification for them also.

MainHeading.P: The rural bus services are another area where a strong need for reform exists. It has been pointed out on a number of occasions in this House that the school transport system as it operates at present is designed to be probably as expensive as it could be. In many cases the school buses are used for nothing other than the transport of children to school. The charges made to the Department of Education are exceptionally high. A 10 per cent fee is payable to CIE when they subcontract the services and also a 4 per cent profit margin is given to CIE when they supply those services directly. That sort of system of charging and the fact that the school buses are used for nothing but school transport cannot but add to the cost of this service. Part of the reason for the unpopular decision that had to be made earlier this year of cutting back the number of children covered by those services must be that limited use of the service. If the school buses were to be integrated into a rural bus service that had more flexibility, and also if there was more private tendering in the area of school transport and in other areas of private transport, we could not but improve the rural transport options. To a large extent that is occurring without Government intervention. Very many private operators have seen the need for a greater flexibility in rural transport and they have moved in on that. It is regrettable that our public transport company have not been able to exploit those openings profitably.

I turn to the McKinsey Report publised some time ago. It is important that the Government take decisions on such reports. That report has been remembered for its suggestions to break up CIE and also its suggestion of the possibility of closing down the railways entirely. Perhaps it is regrettable that those startling recommendations are the only matters for which the report is remembered, because I believe it also had more important short-term recommendations to improve the effectiveness of CIE and these have probably been forgotten.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: It did not recommend closing the railways down.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Speaker.P: I know. All I said was it canvassed the possibility of closing them down. It said it was equally costly to the State to either close them or keep them open without improving them. The fact that it brought up that possibility deflected public debate into an area that moved attention away from its other recommendations.

MainHeading.P: It is worth recording again some of its short-term recommendations. One was that CIE should end the railway's sundries business and allied freight activities. Another was that they should end the area structure of CIE which largely followed from the sundries business. It recommended that comparative road costs for pricing in the freight market should be used, so that CIE on their rail activities would not be pricing themselves out of the market. It recommended the introduciton of the one-man bus operation and that suggestion was endorsed by the Joint Oireachtas Committee when they suggested that a pilot scheme at least should be introduced in the very near future to put that into operation. The report also recommended a full scale route and frequency review by CIE as soon as bus speed improvements were under way. The proposals for bus speed improvements are under way in the city, but we have not yet seen the route frequency review. It recommmended that the Dublin Transport Authority should decide bus service levels in Dublin and pricing policy and it also recommended bringing into the rural scene more options such as smaller buses, private operators and so on. All those recommendations are very reasonable, at least on the surface, and they were well supported by evidence in the McKinsey Report. They deserve greater attention by the Minister in the very near future.

In the area of railway sundries, in 1979 when McKinsey reported it noted that the railways were losing £40 million and that a very sizeable proportion of that loss at that time stemmed not from passenger services where there are obvious social arguments for subsidy, but even freight was losing a substantial amount of money. Freight generally was covering only about three-quarters of its operating cost. There was a loss of about £6 million in the freight service area and the vast bulk came from the railway sundries business. They recommended that closure of the sundries business would save a substantial sum over the years and would not cause great disruption because most of the commercial users had already diversified the vast bulk of their business. This recommendation is one that should have seen more lively discussion at this stage. At present CIE seem to be advertising an expansion in sundries business to make small deliveries around the country. If the losses involved are as great as McKinsey suggests, that decision should be very closely scrutinised by the Minister.

I hope that the Minister will not be put off by very difficult lobbies which will be operating throughout the public transport area. All the major decisions, such as establishing road authorities, bringing in a more sensible system of management within semi-State bodies and reforming road freight are bound to come up against resistance from powerful groups. It is important that the Minister gets a very clear idea of the objectives that have to be achieved because I must emphasise again the enormous importance to the economy of transport. With 16 per cent of GNP being devoted to it and with so many of our competitive industries dependent on an efficient transport system, we cannot afford to hold back from important decisions purely because they may bring short-term unpopularity. I warmly welcome the Minister to what I believe will be a very rewarding task.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Transport (Mr. J. Mitchell) Jim Mitchell
Speaker.P: I thank all Deputies for their thoughtful and constructive contributions to the debate and will reply as far as possible to the many points raised. Some of the issues raised during the debate invlove matters of major importance and would require more time and thought than the circumstances of an Estimates debate would allow. I refer, for example, to the fundamental questions raised by Deputy Wilson as to the conflict between the needs of State bodies to exercise their specialised skills without interference of a political or meddlesome nature and the equal need, in today's altered financial circumstances, for closer monitoring by the State. This is a matter that I know exercises the minds of Ministers of Transport in other European countries. I have discussed the matter with them but none of them has so far reconciled the conflict. It is a matter that concerns me deeply and I will strenuously pursue my efforts to find a balanced and rational answer.

Deputy Wilson similarly raised another fundamental question in relation to CIE. There has, as the Deputy is aware, been increasing acceptance of the view that public moneys must be utilised productively and that results commensurate with costs ought to be achieved. This view is in conflict with the other view, urged with equal force, that special emphasis must be laid on the social role of the public transport system. It is, again, one of those areas, where there is a basic conflict of philosophies and I will give it, also, serious thought in order to define or redefine if necessary the optimum role of the road and rail services in Ireland in the financial circumstances which face us in the foreseeable future.

MainHeading.P: Deputy Cowen expressed concern at the high level of CIE fares. I am extremely conscious that CIE fares are high. It is, however, another way of saying that transport is a very costly service to provide, which of course it is. The question of fares is, in any event, part of the whole dilemma affecting CIE. How can we maintain service, how can we keep the subvention in check? How can we ensure that fares are pitched at the right level to allow people to use the services and indeed to attract users?

These are the questions to which I am addressing myself in tackling the short, medium and long term problems of CIE and I am hoping for some progress at a reasonably early date. Meanwhile, Deputies will not overlook that the National Prices Commission maintains a continuous active role in relation to CIE fares.

Deputy Wilson advanced some views on forcing people to use the railways. It is in the national interest that our railways are used to the maximum extent possible and we must encourage and promote the use of that national asset. I find, however, some contradiction in the Deputy's position because when he turns to road freight he advocates liberalisation. He is no doubt aware that restrictions imposed on other forms of transport since the thirties were designed to strongly influence the overall position of the railways in the transport sector and many of them at this stage must be judged as having failed in their objective. If not, the position of the railways would be otherwise. Furthermore, the restrictions hindered the creation of an effective commercial road freight industry.

There is no point at this stage in thinking in terms of forcing people on to the railways. That is not to say that the railway has no merits, as it has a valuable contribution to make within the framework of our overall transport needs.

Deputy Wilson also asked about the use of the Dublin-Belfast railway line for freight transport. Northern Ireland Railways do not operate a rail freight service and CIE are, therefore, the sole freight carriers on this line. The board operate a full range of freight services; the present freight traffic on the line is at least as good as in other sections of the board's network.

Deputy Byrne referred to the Limerick Junction-Waterford line. CIE have considered a reduction in the level of service on this line on a number of occasions in the past few years. What has been recently considered is the elimination of passenger service only and in the section between Limerick Junction and Waterford only. I have asked CIE to hold over their consideration until the overall strategy for 1983 is settled and so as to allow local interests to make their case. If there must be cuts, I will be anxious to ensure that no part of the country has to bear more than its fair share, and that will be my main concern.

Deputy Durkan mentioned the question of safety on the railway, particularly in relation to the movement of chemicals such as those being carried to Asahi. I am very conscious of this matter and I can assure the Deputy that strict operating rules are in existence regarding this traffic. These rules were drawn up by a committee under the aegis of my Department, a committee which included representatives of CIE, industry, the relevant Government Departments and other interested parties. In addition an accident procedure has been drawn up so that, in the event of any mishap to this traffic, a plan is ready to move into operation.

Deputy Wilson and Deputy Brennan, and Deputy Bruton just now referred to the McKinsey recommendations on the future of CIE. As the House will appreciate, when I became Minister for Transport I set about identifying the problems in the sector with a view to determining my priorities. In the case of CIE, immediate and short-term issues would not keep and had to be dealt with at the expense of longer term issues. The McKinsey Report is very much part of my programme of work and I will tackle it as soon as possible. I expect to be making recommendations to the Government within the next few months and, I hope, a decision will be taken on McKinsey during the year.

Deputy Skelly referred to the value of a subway system for Dublin. Deputies will be aware that CIE have proposals for a rapid transit system, including underground connections for the Dublin area. I would remind Deputies that, when the Transport Consultative Commission reported in 1980 on transport in Dublin, they took a very guarded line in relation to rapid transit and suggested that those proposals required very careful evaluation and ranking in order of worth. This is the correct approach. I envisage the Dublin Transport Authority, when established, carrying out the necessary evaluations. When these have been completed, the rapid transit issue can be further considered.

Deputy Séamus Brennan advocated the installation of a busway on a section of the former Harcourt Street-Bray railway line. Introduction of a busway on the route of the Harcourt Street line was one of the recommendations in the Rapid Transit Study commissioned by CIE. It will be a matter for the DTA, when established, to advise on the priorities as between this and other transport investment proposals for the Dublin area.

In my opening speech I dealt fairly extensively with the prospective role and functions of the Dublin Transport Authority. I can tell Deputy Wilson and Deputy Brennan that the serious issues they raised about traffic and transport in the Dublin area will fall almost entirely within the areas of responsibility of the Authority. As I said, I hope the Authority will be established later this year.

A number of Deputies referred to the Bombardier buses. Under the arrangements between CIE and Bombardier (Ireland) Ltd., CIE provided the premises at Shannon and all the assets of which they retain ownership. Bombardier are resonsible for the purchase of materials for the manufacture of buses, in consultation with CIE, for the employmentmanagement of staff and the production of buses.

CIE requirements for new buses are now supplied from the Bombardier factory in Shannon. CIE's capital allocation for road passenger projects this year is some £16 million which has enabled the board to place an order for 116 buses with Bombardier. To date, over 300 new double deck buses and 50 single deck buses have been supplied from the plant.

As Deputies are aware, the longer-term prospects for the plant are closely linked to the export possibilities for the Bombardier range of buses. I understand that the company are making all possible efforts to secure export orders and we must hope that they will be successful.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: I thought they told me they had got an order.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: Deputy Cowen raised a number of questions about the operation of the Bombardier buses. I should say that CIE have assured me that the Bombardier buses represent a vast improvement on the fleet of Atlanteans which preceded them and that many of the allegations made against the Bombardier buses are exaggerated. For example, it has been directly reported to me that some bus crews regard Bombardiers as the best buses they have ever had. I have also had a reassuring technical report from CIE on the criticisms that have been made.

Many appear to represent the teething problems normal to new equipment in every field of mechanical activity. Some of the problems are not problems at all. The Bombardier has been designed to allow for ready interchange of some components. If there is, for example, an engine which is better for financial or mechanical or operational reasons than that originally specified, it is CIE's duty to seek it out and use it.

Deputy Cowen also raised questions about the road freight services operated by CIE. The CIE road freight service is a marginal and, incidentally, non-subventible activity. Contrary to what many people may believe, CIE discharge only a very minor role in the total road freight market, and it is one that costs them money they have no means of finding.

MainHeading.P: This state of affairs is far from being the wish of this or any previous Government. The fact is that, for a full quarter of a century, every possible resource in legislation, policy and enforcement was invoked to secure for CIE a major and dominant role in the freight and road freight markets. The sum total of all those efforts was that major users throughout the country turned increasingly to the use of their own vehicles and CIE were left out in the cold.

This situation is not unique to Ireland. Similar policies have failed throughout Europe and produced the same result — the growth of own account transport. Even those countries such as Germany which was mentioned by Deputy Wilson have not been remarkably successful in their policy designed to direct freight into the railways.

Deputy Skelly raised points about obtrusive advertising by CIE on bridges, and so forth, which detracts from the visual environment. He conceded that the matter was a minor one, but it raises an important principle. In these hard times, every penny that CIE can earn will count. Their estimate for advertising revenue this year is of the order of £1.6 million. I urge them with, of course, due regard to good taste, to seek to augment these revenues and to find other, even if minor, means of adding to their sources of income.

Deputy Prendergast asked about progress on a new CIE wages grade pension scheme. Negotiations between CIE and the relevant staff representatives on a new scheme are continuing. I have great sympathy with the aspirations of the staff and I hope that progress can be made. When the scheme is agreed, it will be considered by the Government in the light of the prevailing financial circumstances.

Deputy Wilson inquired whether the sale of Ostanna Iompair Éireann's Belfast hotel had been completed and whether any policy decisions had been taken in relation to OIE. The sale of the Russel Court Hotel in Belfast is, of course, primarily a matter for OIE. I understand from the company that a contract for the sale has been signed and that the sale is to be completed by end June. The sale price is a matter between OIE and the purchaser. I have been reviewing the operations of OIE generally and I expect to be in a position shortly to bring proposals before Government on the future operation of the Great Southern Hotels.

Deputy Prendergast raised the question of those who are moving, as he put it “illegitimately” into road transport operations. The legislation in relation to road passenger transport is extremely difficult to enforce. This is the experience in other countries as well as our own. Obviously the line between club or private hire transport and operations which require a licence is a very narrow one. The fears about these alleged illegal services are exaggerated. They cater for traffic much of which they themselves have generated and which would for the most part disappear if the services were terminated.

In relation to Deputy Byrne's point about the activities of foreign hauliers. I should say that complaints about illegal haulage activities are initially and, indeed, primarily for the Garda Síochána.

Deputy Wilson asked for an indication of my thinking on the report of the Transport Consultative Commission on Road Freight Haulage. As I said in my opening speech, I have been considering the TCC Report and I have had discussions with the main interests concerned. I appreciate that the industry and those who may be planning to invest in the industry need early clarification of the Government's intentions in relation to the recommendations in the report. In general I am in favour of the removal of quantitative restrictions on road hauliers subject to the application of high standards in the industry. I will be making proposals to Government in the matter very shortly and I will bring the necessary legislation before the Dáil at the earliest possible date.

Deputy Wilson inquired as to whether the three £10 million equity tranche scheme was being put in place. As I explained in introducing the recent Air Companies (Amendment) Bill, the Government have decided to make available £30 million by way of equity. The money is now being made available in two tranches of £15 million, the first of which was handed over to Aerlínte at the end of March. The second tranche is due to be paid before 31 March 1984.

In reply to another point raised by Deputy Wilson, I should say that traditionally, Aer Lingus's cross-channel and continental services manage a break-even or close to break-even result. Cross-channel traffic has been down over each of the past three years, while continental traffic has also been feeling the effects of the recession. The current year is showing signs of being another difficult one on the traffic front. Overall, Aer Lingus would hope that, with the help of profits from their ancillary activities, their results for 1983-84 can show a small profit.

Deputy Wilson inquired if the provision in the Estimates would be sufficient to cover subsidisation of the Dublin-Derry service for the year. The position is that the agreement concluded between my Department and the airline providing the service, Avair, was for a two-year period expiring in May, 1983. In framing the Estimates for 1983, it was considered inappropriate to include financial provision for payments that would run beyond the expiry date of the present agreement. However, I can inform Deputy Wilson that the subsidy for the service will be continued for the remainder of 1983 and the question of the subsidy arrangements that will apply thereafter in respect of the service is a matter currently under examination in my Department.

Speaker.P: Good man, yourself.

Speaker.P: Deputy Wilson referred to the proposed £99 fare to be offered by People's Express between New York and London and suggested that this could undo the efforts of ECAC to restore a more favourable operating environment on the North Atlantic. MainHeading.P: In the present instance, I understand that the UK authorities are still considering the People's Express case. I also understand that the service, if it is authorised, will be limited to five services a week. People's Express would, therefore, be providing a very small part of the total capacity between New York and London and it is to be hoped that their arrival on the scene will not bring about another price war of the kind which had led to the collapse of large airlines and the undermining of confidence in the industry.

Deputy Wilson asked about the impact of a reduction in the price of fuel on Aer Lingus. Fuel is, of course one of the major elements of airline costs nowadays and any drop in fuel prices is to be welcomed. Each 1 per cent drop in fuel prices is worth of the order of £400,000 to Aer Lingus and the airline hopes to make a saving of some £3.5 million this year arising from lower fuel prices. Deputies will agree that is a very significant development.

Another matter raised by Deputy Wilson was the provision for works at Dublin Airport. The £2.9 million in the Vote relates to works at all three State Airports. The provision was reduced from £3.2 million to £2.9 million because of the difficult budgetary situation. I am satisfied, however that the amount provided will be sufficient to cover all essential work including the overlay on the main runway at Dublin Airport. As I mentioned in my opening speech, this will cost £1.2 million. Work on this project has in fact commenced within the last few days and will be completed in about three months. While this work will prolong the life of the existing runway for a number of years, Aer Rianta and my Department are actively examining the airport's long-term runway requirements.

I dealt comprehensively with the position about the Dublin Airport catering concession in replying to a parliamentary question last week. Deputy Wilson, in his contribution, referred to a comment made by Deputy Haughey about the high quality restaurant service offered by Aer Rianta at Dublin Airport in the past. In that connection, I should say that the SAS proposals envisage a wide range of services, including the restoration of a first-class restaurant facility.

Speaker.P: Irish food and cuisine, I hope.

Deputy Wilson suggested that the Federal Express proposal might be revived. The Federal Express concept had very real attractions for Shannon. Unfortunately, our latest information is that Federal Express are having a major re-think on the whole concept of a transatlantic operation and that the chances of their proceeding with the project are not good, at least in the short term. Aer Rianta and SFADCo are continuing to keep in close contact with developments.

Deputy Wilson asked about the position in relation to Mount Gabriel. The radar facility at Mount Gabriel was provided in February 1980 to monitor aircraft movements in the upper airspace. The capital cost was borne by Eurocontrol, an international agency concerned with air traffic control services in Europe, and the operational costs are shared by the Department of Transport and by the UK Civil Aviation Authority.

There are two radar “heads” involved and Eurocontrol have decided to proceed with the restoration of one of the heads, at a cost of about £250,000. The question of the restoration of the other head, which was extensively damaged and the general question of financial liability remain to be resolved but there is no question of any payment from the Vote now under consideration by the Dáil.

MainHeading.P: A number of questions were asked by Deputy Wilson about the regulations for travel trade licensing. I had hoped to be in a position to publish the implementing regulations in February 1983 but was unable to do so because the Irish Travel Agents Association asked me to consider proposals for revision of a number of aspects of the draft regulations. Even if I had found it possible to meet this target date, I would still have had to allow a six-month lead-in time to ensure ample time for the submission and examination of applications for licences, the negotiation of bonds and the issue of licences in good time before the scheme became operational. The date of 1 November 1983 was chosen to coincide with the start of the traditional winter season in the travel trade.

On and from 1 November it will be illegal to trade as a tour operator or travel agent without a licence under the Transport (Tour Operators and Travel Agents) Act, 1982. In the examination of applications for licences under the new regime, applicants will need a bond and, in addition, will have to satisfy me that they have the necessary financial, business and organisational resources and that they are fit and proper persons to carry on business as a tour operator or travel agent as the case may be.

In the meantime my Department will continue to insist, as a condition of all charter authorisations, that the carriers involved will repatriate any travellers who may be affected by financial problems experienced by tour operators or travel agents. In addition the rescue and protection fund established voluntarily by the ITAA will be available in respect of all holidays booked with member companies of that association. I understand that despite the impact of a recent collapse the association still have at their disposal substantial funds to protect travellers up to the commencement of the new statutory protection measures on 1 November. The association recently indicated to me that they might be prepared to integrate their rescue resources with the Travellers' Protection Fund which I am establishing under the new Act but no firm proposals have as yet been made to me by the association in the matter.

As regards Deputy Wilson's reference to the Appropriations-in-aid, I should make it clear that these represent the revenue from licence application fees and will help to offset the administrative costs of running the scheme. There is no connection between the Appropriations-in-aid provision and the statutory fund which will, of course, be accounted for separately.

He asked if I will consider the possible extension of the Cork-Pembroke route when I look at the results at the end of the tourist season. I would be very happy if we could have a year-round service again. However, the route has been very unprofitable for the B & I when operated on a year-round basis. I will be having the performance of the summer service examined at the end of the season and I will be reserving my position in the meantime. He also asked if I am satisfied that the loss figures on the Cork-Pembroke route were properly computed. For this I have to rely on the figures furnished to me by the company but I have no reason to doubt the accuracy of the figures provided.

Deputy Wilson asked if I am satisfied that financial control of the ferry services is adequate. My information here is that the company have a comprehensive range of financial control procedures covering all aspects of the vessel operations. The Deputy may wish to know that a senior executive of the B & I has recently been given special resposibility for all operating aspects of the car ferry services. On the operation of the Dublin-Holyhead route, I understand that the route is making a positive contribution this year as it did in 1982. I am not prepared to give detailed figures because of commercial considerations.

B & I operate a daily service in contrast to Sealink's twice daily service. There are similar fare structures and regular consultation between both companies on marketing policies adopted by each company from time to time. I understand that B & I carryings are in line with budget expectations. I recently visited Holyhead and was impressed by the measure of co-operation which I observed and by the strong indications of local support for the B & I service which is a change from the situation that pertained a year ago.

Deputy Wilson also asked about the Jetfoil. The Jetfoil is at present laid up in Arklow. The B & I have been pursuing the possibility of a sale or lease of the craft. There have been a number of promising inquiries world-wide but the vessel has not been disposed of yet. Deputy Wilson inquired about the level of equity which will be available for B&I and Irish Shipping in 1983. I can only say that the financial position of B & I and Irish Shipping will shortly be considered by the Government and the Deputy will appreciate that I cannot anticipate the decision of the Government in this regard.

In reply to another question, I can inform Deputies that the bulk carrier Irish Spruce will be delivered to Irish Shipping Limited in June 1983. Deputy Wilson also asked about Irish Shipping's share in Oceanbank.

The position is that Oceanbank Developments Limited are the holding company for Irish Shipping's interests in ferries, insurance and property. Irish Shipping have a 75 per cent share of the company, the other 25 per cent being held by Allied Irish Investment Bank. Another question was asked about the operation of Belfast Car Ferries. I understand that Belfast Car Ferries, an Oceanbank subsidiary company, are doing very well. They commenced operations last year and are operating profitably.

Deputy Byrne raised some questions about Rosslare Harbour. There has been very substantial State investment in Rosslare Harbour in recent years and the benefits of this investment are evident in the frequency of shipping services now using the port. I realise that the passenger handling facilities, could be improved and I will certainly consider the Deputy's representations in the light of the moneys available and the various demands on them. I am very much aware of the activities and proposals of the Harbour Development Board. Indeed the Minister of State, Deputy Donnellan, met the board last September. The particular question of establishing a State company or State agency for the development of a particular region is a matter for the Minister for Industry and Energy and the Minister for Trade, Commerce and Tourism. My understanding is that the board agreed to pursue the proposals with those Ministers.

I dealt with the matter of the completion of the customs building at Rosslare Harbour in reply to a Dáil question on 21 April 1983. As I said then, the completion of the extension of the customs building is primarily a matter for CIE who manage and operate Rosslare Harbour. CIE are unlikely to be able to undertake the work from within their capital budget this year and, due to the severe financial constraints on the Exchequer, no allocation is possible from the Transport Vote this year.

The question of berthage facilities at Rosslare Harbour, which was referred to in the course of this debate by Deputy Byrne, has been raised periodically by various interested parties and Deputies from the constituency. CIE have indicated that on average the scheduled usage of the two piers at the harbour is approximately 30 per cent. Delays, when they occur, are mainly due to ships running behind schedule due to weather conditions.

Deputy Byrne also raised the question of the supply of beach nourishment material to Rosslare Strand. In reply to a Dáil question recently I stated that CIE had under consideration proposals to dredge 120,000 cubic metres, 180,000 tonnes, of material at Rosslare Harbour using a trailing suction dredging vessel and that it was intended to dump the dredged material inshore from where it would be moved onto the Rosslare Strand by tidal action. I understand from CIE that a contract has now been placed for this work to be carried out and that operations will commence shortly.

I have noted the comments of Deputy Taylor-Quinn on the setting up of a Shannon estuarial authority. I am prepared to discuss the question of establishing such an authority with representatives of various ports concerned before taking any decision on the matter. I will have arrangements for these discussions made as soon as possible.

Deputy Taylor-Quinn also raised the question of comparison between the 1983 Estimate figures for salaries and the 1982 provisional outturn figures. I would point out that as the latter figures are provisional, they require further adjustment before being finalised for the Appropriation Account. In relation to the difference in average pay levels between the Marine Services and the Meteorological Services I should explain that the bulk of those employed in the Marine Services are highly paid professional personnel while in the Meteorological Services there is a wide range of grades and the majority of their personnel are in the lower recruitment grades.

Deputy Morley asked if I am prepared to make money available when required for the completion of the Connaught Regional Airport. As I indicated recently in response to a Dáil question, the grave Exchequer situation dictates a review of the present position whereby the State is 100 per cent liable for all costs of this project and a decision on the matter will be made shortly.

I am grateful to Deputy Wilson for the constructive and supportive interest he expressed in the staffing of my Department and particularly the Planning Unit. My Department are, in fact, short of the heads of staff the Deputy numerated but the reasons lie, of course, in the severe economic disciplines at present imposed on Government Departments. Apart from raising questions of importance on all aspects of the transport sector, Deputies have also made valuable suggestions which I will have carefully considered in my Department.

Almost all our transport companies are in very severe financial difficulties. MainHeading.Title: Estimates, 1983. - Vote 27: Environment.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Spring) Dick Spring
Speaker.P: I move:

That a sum not exceeding £606,009,000 be granted to defray the charge which will come in course of payment during the year ending on the 31st day of December, 1983 for the salaries and expenses of the Office of the Minister for the Environment, including grants in lieu of rates on agricultural land and other grants to local authorities, grants and other expenses in connection with housing and miscellaneous schemes, subsidies and grants including certain grants-inaid.

In presenting this Estimate to the Dáil I will speak briefly about the different categories of expenditure involved before dealing with specific subheads. The gross provision for my Department is nearly £636 million, which is the fourth largest Vote in money terms.

This gives some idea of the large amount of funds involved especially as it does not include a further £454 million for non-voted capital expenditure in the current year. The Vote for the Department of the Environment can be subdivided into six broad categories: grants or recoupment of expenditure to local authorities, subsidies to local authorities for loan charges for specific services, direct departmental payments, grants or grants-in-aid to voluntary, semi-State or international bodies, departmental administration and receipts classified as appropriations-in-aid.

The grants or recoupment to local authorities account for £415 million, 65 per cent of the total amount, and cover grants in lieu of domestic and agricultural rates, road grants, public water supply grants, environmental works, local improvement schemes, malicious injuries and other smaller grants.

MainHeading.P: The subsidies to local authorities towards their loan charges amount to over £162 million or 26 per cent of the Vote and comprise subsidies for loan charges for local authority housing, including private sites and the former low rise mortgage scheme, water supply and sewerage, public library service, rehabilitation of travelling people and for fire services.

The direct departmental payments total nearly £40 million or 6 per cent and are mainly for grants to private persons for housing, water and sewerage and the mortgage subsidy scheme. The grants to various bodies cover such organisations as An Foras Forbartha, National Road Safety Association, Medical Bureau of Road Safety, Dublin Inner City Group, Fire Prevention Council, An Bord Pleanála and other smaller bodies.

The general administrative expenses of the Department are included in subheads A1 to D. The expenditure involved is £12.4 million or 2 per cent of the Vote. Every effort is being made in my Department to maximise efficiency and to deploy staff resources to the best possible advantage.

As stated above, the bulk of the funds are given in the form of grants and subsidies to local authorities to assist them to provide services such as water supply, waste collection, roads, fire services, libraries, etc. The rates relief for domestic premises and agricultural land now being provided by the Exchequer has meant major relief for individual households.

The provision in the Environment Vote is part only of what will be spent this year on the services of my Department and the local authorities operating under the aegis of my Department. Money for the services also comes from some other Votes, from the Local Loans Fund and of course from local authorities' own resources arising from rates and miscellaneous items of income.

When all these are reckoned it is estimated that the Department and the local authorities will spend some £1,400 million on current and capital expenditure in 1983. This figure compares with about £1,250 million in 1982. The local authorities will have more than £1,300 million to spend this year and they will themselves raise more than £300 million of this amount.

It is evident that spending on this scale, capital and current, is of major significance not only in terms of the variety of public services provided and their importance in the life of the community, but also of the direct and indirect impact on economic activity and generation of employment. It is, of course, essential that the local government system within which the expenditure is undertaken should be working well and efficiently. The question of improving the structure of the system in ways which might make it more effective has been under consideration on and off for several years. This, as my predecessors can vouch, is a complex subject with wide ramifications. I intend, however, to examine the issues involved and the options as regards changes which would contribute to making the system stronger, more effective and more democratic. The future financial health of the system is, of course, central to such consideration, and I will come back to that.
I will now deal with the major expenditure areas of my Department.

First, I want to talk now about the building industry. I have heard many figures bandied about recently in relation to public capital support for the industry in 1983 and all sorts of dire predictions for output and employment which grossly distort the true position. There is no doubt that the building industry has been going through a lean period and it would be strange, indeed, if it remained untouched by the recessionary conditions the country has been enduring. The result of these conditions has been a massive drop in investment of private capital in the building industry over an extended period. In the four-year period 1979-1982, private investment in the industry fell by over 50 per cent. It is unrealistic to expect the State to match in full this reduction in private investment by a corresponding increase in public capital support, given the competing needs of other sectors of the economy and the restriction on the raising of revenue through taxation and on borrowing by the State.

Public capital investment in the building industry has in fact gone a long way towards countering the worst effects of the withdrawal of private investment and every effort is being made to maintain this position.

In the years 1977 to 1979 there was greatly increased public capital expenditure on construction at a time when building activity, buoyed up with private investment, was rising strongly in any event. The result was a costly and damaging over-heating of the industry and the creation of serious problems, many of which we are still trying to cope with. Inflation in the industry literally took off. Tender prices jumped far ahead of cost increases generally. Shortages of many building materials gave rise to greatly increased imports. Shortages of skilled workers became manifest. Delays in completing projects because of unavailability of building workers in some areas caused further increases in project costs.
