So one or other of these lines, I conclude, was deliberately and continuously under surveillance by somebody who had no business to put it under surveillance and no show or colour of legal authority, even of the kind that Deputy Doherty would call legal authority, to carry out such a surveillance.

That is the first conclusion for which I hope members of the Government would accept — naturally they are not responsible — in a sense, the need to be interested. The other line of reflection which this episode induces in me is something which naturally no Government could be expected to have any departmental interest in, so to speak. That is the fact that a responsible union leader could lend himself, first of all, to the gathering and then to the use of a transcript of this kind, could use this material with this explanation. Secondly the fact that, as I said before, the press should let this matter pass with an almost zero degree of interest.

I hope it is not going to become the case here that, merely because the bugging of journalists caused a convulsion a few months ago which resulted in resignations, rows, and generally in the roof falling in, public interest must now be deemed to be suspended in all such matters when people other than journalists are involved. I hope that is not the case. Let me say that I believe the honour of the journalists I know at least would not allow me to think that. It may be that they are just so punch-drunk from reading about bugging and transcriptions of telephone conversations that they have lost interest for the moment in this whole theme, and that interest will, in due course of nature, revive. That may be so; I hope it is so. I do not accept and I do not believe any ordinary reflecting citizen of this country would accept that privacy is anything but indivisible, that it is a quality and a right, yes, Sir, and a constitutional right, to which everyone in this country is equally entitled and that a breach of that right is no more outrageous when committed on a journalist than when committed on an insurance company executive or when committed on a trade union official.

Although The Irish Times editorial of yesterday was broadly speaking, in a national sense, a helpful and good editorial, I am sorry to say that there slipped through their pen the following description of this episode: “Crossed Lines!” was how they headed it and it commenced:
With the story of the alleged cross telephone lines we are back in the land of the grotesque, unbelievable, bizarre etc. ... a black comedy of errors to lighten our darkness just a little.

There was no error here, sir, this was deliberate; it is black all right but it is not a comedy. It may be a laugh, as our advertising said in the 1968 Referendum campaign, but it is no joke. I repeat:
... a black comedy of errors to lighten our darkness just a little.

Whose darkness has this episode lightened? Who feels any the lighter of heart for this episode? I do not reprobate an editorial writer under the pressure of time using an expression like that — and it is true that we have had really an overdose of stories about telphone bugs — but I think it important to say that this House would agree with me, that privacy is a constitutional right of citizens. It has been, I will not say judicially declared to be so, but it has been judicially observed to be so by Mr. Justice Budd in the McGee case. I have absolutely no doubt — for what my opinion on the matter is worth — that it is a constitutional right for the breach of which a civil action for damages would lie. I have no doubt that either of these insurance company executives, could he identify whoever it was who deliberately intercepted and recorded his conversation, could recover civil damages against him. I hope that that simple fact will not allow it to become the norm here that one takes transcripts of other people's telephone conversations as part of the ordinary ammunition and give-and-take of industrial or political relations, that we will not simply wave it through, either as politicians or journalists, as something about which one is really being a bit over-solemn in protesting.

I hope I do not need to say — although it arises in the context of industrial relations and the interests of trade unions — I would say the very same thing with just the same vehemence, perhaps more, if what was at issue here was an interception which I believed to have been carried out to suit the interests of employers in the conduct of their affairs with unions. What kind of headlines would we have had over the last couple of days if this episode appeared to have been the other way round, if it appeared to have been the insurance companies that were bugging Mr. Hall? What would have been said by the gentlemen in the press then or by the people on both sides of this House? The Doherty affair would have been in the halfpenny place compared with it, perhaps rightly so.

I want to ask the Minister for Justice, through his colleague before us, to consider whether, in spite of the very defective state of the law in regard to telephones — which I am very glad to see the Minister for Posts and Telegraphs is about to remedy with an amendment to his Postal and Telecommunications Services Bill, 1982, circulated today — the Garda Síochána and the Director of Public Prosecutions might consider whether, perhaps — defective through the law may be — there is some offence here which has been committed by somebody who deliberately interferes with telephone apparatus in order to record somebody else's conversations. I freely admit that it is not obvious or evident to me which section of which Act has been here infringed. But I find it hard to believe that there is not a regulation somewhere with a penalty attached to it which that person has infringed.

I should like to ask the Minister present to make a statement to the Dáil — naturally he cannot do so in the few minutes left to him today — at some moment convenient to himself, on the general state of telephone security. By his amendment circulated today he is proposing to strengthen the law in regard to telephones so as to make it a specific offence, which it has not been until now, to intercept and pass on or record other people's telephone conversations without their consent. That is a good thing and I support it. I have not had a chance to study every line of the amendment but, when I do, I may be able to make suggestions about it. I would like the Minister not only to do that but also to find some opportunity to give an assurance or make a statement in the House on the general question of the physical security of the telephone system. Naturally, there is no such thing as 100 per cent security. It is not enough for the ordinary citizen, the ordinary businessman, the ordinary insurance official, yes, or the ordinary trade union official to know that somebody who intercepts his line is committing a very serious offence; I and the rest of the House would like to know how easy it is physically for an unauthorised interception to be carried out either at the house exchange level, at the local exchange level, out in the countryside on the wires, or however it may be technically possible. Most people are, so to speak, illiterate on the subject of telephone technology; they can hardly be expected to be otherwise. It would be a good thing if the Minister were to give this House some general assurance about how safe and secure a telephone system can be made, apart from whatever security criminal sanctions may afford it.

I should like to conclude by making two quick suggestions to this Minister. First of all, I would suggest that he might consider that where this offence, which he now proposes, of intercepting a telephone communication is committed by one of his own officials, or by one of the officials in the employment of An Bord Telecom, it should be a specially qualified offence with special consequences, because of the natural breach of trust and the natural breach of duty involved, over and above those which would attach to an outsider. Secondly I think his section, at first blush, is defective in as much as it does not seem to provide any special prohibition on the publication, in print, of the transcript of an unlawfully taken conversation. It makes references to “make use of”, something like that, such a transcript. But I think it would be helpful if it were made clear that when a transcript is unlawfully obtained and passed on, any newspaper proprietor or anybody else who publishes it does so at his peril.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. J. Mitchell) Jim Mitchell
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. J. Mitchell)
Speaker.P: If I might deal with the last point Deputy Kelly made, the amendment circulated today proposing a new section 94 of the Postal and Telecommunications Services Bill, 1982, does cover the question of disclosing and says:
New Section 94
In page 43, before section 94, to insert the following new section:
94. (1) A person who—
(a) intercepts or attempts to intercept, or
(b) authorises, suffers or permits another person to intercept, or

(c) does anything that will enable him or another person to intercept, telecommunications messages being transmitted by the company or who discloses the existence, substance or purport of any such message which has been intercepted or uses for any purpose any information obtained from any such message shall be guilty of an offence.
I might add that that section was drafted long before the present incident to which Deputy Kelly referred.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kelly Mr. Kelly
Speaker.P: I accept that, of course.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: I fully share Deputy Kelly's concern in this matter. I have ordered and initiated an inquiry by my chief investigation officer into this matter. That is already under way. For obvious reasons it would be inappropriate for me to indicate the lines such inquiries will take or to comment further on them at this stage. However, I would like to clarify the position so far as my Department are concerned about three issues of a general kind which may give cause for concern arising from the publicity about this matter. These are, first to what extent accidental overhearing of telephone conversations can take place; secondly, under what conditions equipment may be used to record telephone conversations and, thirdly, what safegaurds exist to prevent irregular interception of telephone calls.

MainHeading.P: On the first point I am advised that conditions which give rise to accidental overhearing of telephone conversations occur only to a very limited extent. They can arise due to a fault in a subscriber underground cable, in a junction cable or in a telephone exchange. In the case of a fault in a subscriber underground cable, it is to be expected that the existence of the fault would be evident to the subscriber concerned and would be reported and cleared. In the case of a junction cable, faults arise rarely. They normally come under notice at a very early stage and would be cleared promptly.

In the case of telephone exchanges, faults giving rise to the conditions referred to are most likely to arise in the case of the older type step-by-step exchanges, although they can occur on occasions on the modern crossbar exchange also. However, conditions of the kind occur very infrequently even in the case of step-by-step exchanges. Routine maintenance is carried out on a regular basis in all telephone exchanges but detection of faults which could give rise to overhearing can unfortunately be quite difficult and may not detected during the course of routine maintenance.

About 25 per cent of subscribers in the Dublin area are connected to step-by-step exchanges. The proportion connected to step-by-step exchanges in provincial areas is lower. The step-by-step exchanges are being phased out and are being replaced mainly by digital exchanges most of them by the end of 1985 but they will be with us for some time yet. Their replacement before they become unserviceable would not be justified.

A special programme of preventative maintenance of underground cables in the Dublin area is being carried out this year. This should reduce the incidence of faults but it will not eliminate them; indeed, it is not possible to guarantee that isolated faults involving overhearing will not occur.

The position is therefore that, while every effort is made to guard against conditions which might give rise to accidental overhearing and to correct them promptly on the rare occasions when they occur, it will not be possible in the foreseeable future to guarantee 100 per cent security of the network against occasional overhearing. This is not unique to Ireland. No telephone administration that we know of provide such a guarantee in relation to their networks.

The second point which may give cause for public concern is the use of equipment for recording telephone conversations. It is illegal for anybody to make an attachment of a recorder or other device to a telephone instrument or telephone plant without the express approval of my Department. Approval is given for two types of equipment for recording telephone calls but stringent conditions are attached to safeguard the privacy of telephone conservations. These are that: before a telephone call is recorded, the person making the call must be advised that it is proposed to do so; the existence of a recorder on the installation must be indicated on the subscriber's notepaper on which the telephone number is quoted; and the existence of a recorder must be indicated by a symbol in the subscriber's entry in the telephone directory. Subscribers are required to give a written undertaking in regard to each of the three foregoing conditions before permission is granted to them for attaching a recorder to a telephone installation.

As in the case of conditions giving rise to accidental overhearing, my Department are not in a position for obvious reasons to ensure that all subscribers comply fully with the conditions governing the use of recording devices on telephone installations. Nor indeed can they prevent the irregular use of such devices without authority. However, should such cases come under notice in the course, for example, of maintenance or by way of complaint, the sanctions available include withdrawal of telephone service.

The third point which may give rise to public concern is the safeguards that exist to prevent irregular interception of telephone calls. As I mentioned earlier, it is not possible to guarantee that conditions which may give rise to accidental overhearing of telephone calls will not occur, however rarely. Neither is it possible to guarantee that individual telephone subscribers will not irregularly record telephone conversations without advising the caller in advance. Deliberate unauthorised interception of telephone calls is a separate matter. Safeguards exist against this, details of which it would be inappropriate for me to disclose for obvious reasons. As I mentioned when replying to a recent parliamentary question, these are being reviewed at present.

As a previous Minister for Justice I was knowledgeable about the area of telephone interception and consequently, I have been very concerned to strengthen the law in this general area of the privacy of telephone conversations. I am taking advantage of the Postal and Telecommunications Services Bill to achieve this. As I have said already, and as Deputy Kelly has mentioned today by coincidence, 90 amendments to that Bill have been circulated and these include proposals for making it an offence in itself for anyone to intercept anyone else's telephone call or anyone else's mail. It is proposed to make it a further offence to disclose the substance of any such telephone call or mail. The penalties proposed in this regard are very severe. In the case of a summary offence heard in the District Court there will be a fine of £800 or 12 months' imprisonment or both or, if on indictment, there will be a fine of up to £50,000 or 2 years' imprisonment or both.

Deputy Kelly has suggested that people in the Post Office should be treated separately. For them it is already an offence to intercept or to disclose without lawful authority the contents of a telephone call. In his usual fashion, Deputy Kelly has very lucidly described the gross improbability of what has happened but I do not wish to comment on that pending the outcome of the investigation in progress in my Department.
The Dáil adjourned at 5.30 p.m. until 2.30 p.m. on Tuesday, 17 May 1983.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Structural Reform of Departments.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O.J. Flanagan Mr. O.J. Flanagan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Public Service if he will set out in comprehensive terms the “detailed implementation work” on structural reform now in progress in the eight Government Departments mentioned by him in reply to a parliamentary question by Deputy Flanagan on 19 April on the PSORG report; and when this work will be completed bearing in mind that this report was published in 1969.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Public Service (Mr. Boland) John Boland
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Public Service (Mr. Boland)
Speaker.P: As mentioned in my reply to the Deputy's question of 19 April 1983, the Departments of Health and Transport were reorganised in 1974-76 along the lines recommended in the PSORG report. The published reports (Prl. 3445 and Prl. 4182 respectively) on which these reorganisations were based indicate in some detail the nature of the implementation work involved. Following review of these experiments, the Government decided in October 1977 to restructure all line Departments along similar lines.

In accordance with this decision, all line Departments were invited to prepare draft plans for their reorganisation. Experience showed clearly, however, that an intensive study would be necessary to develop these plans to the stage where they would form a blueprint for detailed reorganisation. Accordingly, in late 1978 and early 1979, a special project team was established in the Department of the Public Service to work with Departments and develop detailed proposals.

The project team, with the help of staff from each of the Departments concerned, carried out the necessary examinations and made recommendations for improved structures and management. The first stage of each exercise was to identify (on the basis of an analysis of each Department's functions and in the light of the requirements at the time) the new structures which could best be introduced in order to improve the working of the Department, within a framework provided by the PSORG recommendations.
This involved consultation with staff interests as well as with the managements of the Departments concerned.

As the Deputy will appreciate, a Government Department is a major enterprise by any standard (the Department of Agriculture alone employs over 5,000 people); consequently these were virtually all major assignments.
New structures in broad terms were designed and agreed with the eight Departments mentioned in my reply of 19 April 1983.

MainHeading.P: The next step is the “detailed implementation work” referred to by the Deputy in his question. This is currently in progress and involves detailed field work with analysis of systems, procedures and processes. These analyses are resulting in specific and detailed individual proposals on the establishment of executive offices, the functions and responsibilities of the management of those offices and the relationships of the offices with the Minister and with other bodies. This work commenced at various times, depending on the availability of joint resources, from late 1979 onwards.

Change on this scale is obviously a slow process, as basic procedures must be examined, recommendations developed, agreed with management and communicated to and, where appropriate, negotiated with staff interests.

Departments have, of course, changed substantially since 1969 and continue to change. There is no question of recommending structures which will not meet the needs of the latter quarter of the twentieth century. Departments have to be adapted to meet constantly changing roles and responsibilities. The current examinations are taking account of these changes.

This reorganisation work will be brought to completion as part of the comprehensive reviews of administrative efficiency, schemes and programmes which are now being stepped up in all Departments. The Government will shortly consider the question of the operative date for these organisational changes.
